entry.title: svn revert cleanup
entry.content:
You have reverted an svn merge and you have a lot of files not tracked (with exclamation mark, basically)?
Clean it up:
svn status | awk '$1 == "?" {print $2}' | xargs -t -i rm -r {}

Again, knowing awk and xargs turn helpful!

entry.title: the correct procedure for compiling subversion 1.6.2
entry.content:
Not sure if this is the complete way of doing it (I'm not telling you which .deb to install), but it worked for me:

Remove some waste from eventual previous compilations:
```

$ rm -rf /usr/loca/lib/libsvn
$ rm -rf /usr/local/lib/libapr
$ rm -rf /usr/local/lib/libexpat
$ rm -rf /usr/local/lib/libneon
```

Run autogen
```

$ ./autogen.sh
```

Configure and install (it is important to follow the order)
```

$ ./configure
$ make -j external-all
$ make -j local-all
$ sudo make install
```

That's it. Hope to have helped someone as usual.

entry.title: svn: Entry has unexpectedly changed special status
entry.content:
If you have this error after tryin a commit, for sure you have replaced a standard file with a symlink or viceversa, haven't you?

In that case, what you have to do is just svn add and svn will replace the file with the new one!

Were you already scared :D ?

Anyway, the correct procedure to replace a real file with a symlink in svn is the following:

  1. svn remove of the file you want to link

  2. ln -s

  3. svn add of the new link

;)

entry.title: quick solution to "svn: Checksum mismatch ..."
entry.content:
If this error afflict your quiet development day, I'm sorry :D I had this problem today and I solved in few steps:

  1. make a backup of the working copy in a different directory
  2. delete only the corrupted directory from your working copy
  3. make an svn update
  4. copy back only the modified files you need from the backup copy to the current working copy
  5. commit your changes Now breath deeply and take a cold shower: I suppose you must be sweat! :D
